L1_summary_of_paper: The paper asks whether rivals’ alliances increase or decrease the competitive pressure a focal firm experiences and whether firms can counter those effects by collaborating with those rivals. It distinguishes alliance types—horizontal (with competitors), upstream (with knowledge suppliers like universities), and downstream (with commercialization partners like pharma/marketing)—and develops a framework combining RBV/TCE logics of resource access/foreclosure with organizational ecology’s carrying capacity/legitimation logic. Constructs include rivals’ alliance counts by type, partners’ alliance counts, network efficiency, and focal firm exit (discrete‑time hazard). Context is Canadian biotechnology, 1991–1996; data come from the Canadian Biotechnology directory and U.S. patent records. Main findings: rivals’ alliances generally raise a focal firm’s exit risk, with the effect strongest for horizontal, weaker for upstream, and weakest/mostly null for downstream; partnering with well‑connected rivals reduces exit risk for most partner types; rivals’ network efficiency raises hazard; focal firms’ own alliances with pharma/chemical/university reduce hazard; patenting patterns have asymmetric effects (rivals’ recent/pending patents increase hazard, rivals’ older patents decrease it). Contributions: introduces alliance‑type contingent competitive effects via foreclosure vs. carrying capacity, bridges RBV/TCE with ecological competition models, and shifts attention from effects on participants to effects on rivals and group‑versus‑group dynamics in alliance networks.
M3_unit_of_analysis_element: Other: Rivals’ alliance portfolio by partner type
A1_citation: Silverman, B. S., & Baum, J. A. C. (2002). Alliance-Based Competitive Dynamics. Academy of Management Journal, 45(4), 791–806.
C1_constructs: Other: Carrying capacity/legitimation from external ties
D2_identification: Other: Discrete-time hazard (conditional logit) with time-varying controls and left-truncation correction
D2_key_assumptions_addressed: Time dependence addressed with yearly spells
D5_data_sources: National Research Council of Canada (financing aggregates)
U.S. biotech firm counts/patents from prior dataset
E4_moderators: Alliance type (horizontal vs upstream vs downstream)
F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Alliance lists are self-reported; cannot distinguish equity vs non‑equity ties or alliance duration; potential simultaneity between alliances and exit risk; omitted variables (e.g., pipeline quality) may confound estimates; no explicit correction for endogenous partner selection.
F3_saturation_contribution: Other: Extends prior (focus on effects on nonparticipants)
G1_construct_mapping_note: Map rivals’ alliances to two latent forces: (i) partner foreclosure (strong for horizontal, moderate for upstream, weak for downstream); (ii) carrying capacity/legitimation expansion (strong for downstream, weak for horizontal).
G4_unifying_props_drafts: Rivals’ horizontal alliances primarily operate via partner foreclosure, raising focal exit risk.
Rivals’ downstream alliances primarily operate via carrying capacity/legitimation, attenuating competitive pressure.
Partnering with well‑connected rivals converts some rival‑alliance advantages into focal advantages through information access and signaling.
I1_mechanism_statements: Horizontal alliances consume scarce competitor‑partner slots, foreclosing others’ access and intensifying rivalry.
Upstream alliances limit access to star scientists and tacit knowledge (moderate foreclosure) with limited carrying capacity spillovers.
Downstream alliances inject capital/legitimacy and spur follower entry by other downstream firms, expanding carrying capacity and dampening net competitive pressure.
Alliances with well‑connected rivals grant faster knowledge access and positive signals, reducing exit risk for the focal firm.

I2_mediation_moderation_details.role_in_link: Moderates the effect of rivals’ alliance counts on focal exit (horizontal > upstream > downstream).
More efficient rival networks amplify competitive pressure (higher exit hazard).
Rival‑partners’ patents and scope narrowness strengthen the hazard‑reducing effect of collaborating with them.

I3_theoretical_propositions: H1a: A firm’s exit rate increases as its rivals’ number of alliances increases.
H1b: The increase in exit rate is lower for rivals’ upstream than for horizontal alliances.
H1c: The increase in exit rate is lower for rivals’ downstream than for upstream or horizontal alliances.
H2: A firm’s exit rate decreases as its rival‑partners’ number of alliances increases.
J1_main_findings_summary: Rivals’ alliances raise focal exit hazard overall, with the largest effect from rivals’ horizontal alliances; upstream effects are smaller/mixed; downstream effects are largely null or weak.
Collaborating with well‑connected rivals generally lowers exit hazard; exceptions include when those partners ally with other biotech firms or marketing firms.
Rivals’ network efficiency (diverse, non‑redundant partner mix) increases focal exit hazard; focal firms’ own network efficiency reduces it.
Patents: rivals’ recent/pending patents increase focal hazard; rivals’ older patents reduce it; focal firms’ own older/pending patents reduce hazard.
J2_finding_evidence_links: Hypotheses and alliance-type logic: pp. 793–796. Methods/data: pp. 795–798 (variables in Table 1). Results: Table 2 and discussion pp. 799–801. Conclusion/implications: pp. 800–801.
K1_contribution_summary: This study reframes alliances as competitive weapons whose effects on nonparticipants depend on alliance type: horizontal alliances intensify rivalry via partner foreclosure; downstream alliances expand carrying capacity and can mitigate pressure; upstream sit in between. It also shows that co‑opting well‑connected rivals through collaboration can convert rival advantages into focal survival benefits, and it offers an integrative bridge between RBV/TCE and ecological models to study asymmetric, group‑level competitive dynamics in alliance networks.
